sections.chapter: Working with the built-in capabilities of the SDK
sections.title: AdSDK Cache Management

inlineContent.text: The SDK supports a persistent cache with resources related to ad, these can be banners or other resources, depending on the type of ad. In this tutorial, we’ll look at how an application developer can control the cache.
We will continue to build the app, so be sure to follow all the previous tutorials. You can download
which has already implemented all steps from this tutorial.
Let’s open
and focus on the
method.
The cache size parameter is optional. If you do not specify it, the default cache size is 100 MB.
As you may have noticed, when creating an
, we specify the size of our cache in MB. Let’s change it to 20 MB.
If the specified cache size is smaller than the size of already cached resources, the cache will delete resources to fit the new specified limit.
In addition, the SDK allows you to change the size of the cache over time. You can use
method for this purpose.
In this section, we will learn how to limit the size of the cache.
We’ll continue in the
file. Let’s imagine a situation in which some ads can be localized. In this case, you would like to clear the entire cache so that when the ad is reloaded, it will be correctly localized.
Let’s add the functionality of tracking localization changes. To do this, we want to react to a change in
and call the
method.
All we have to do is clear the cache. To do this, we use the
method. Congratulations, now all ad resources will be removed every time the user changes the language of the app.
Although the cache size reached to it limit, SDK will removes resources in FIFO order, sometimes you need to clear the cache completely. In this section, we will learn how we can do this.

sections.title: Custom handling of target tap URLs

abstract.text: Sometimes you need to handle taps in your own way. For example, to display ads in the internal browser in the app. In this tutorial, we will learn how to customise the SDK’s tap handling behaviour.
AdSDK provides powerful functionality for user tagging and conversion tracking. In this tutorial, we will look at this functionality.
do a lot of work under the hood and can send messages about them to the app. In turn, you can monitor and react to it in some way. In this tutorial, we’ll look at what events are handled by
and how we can interact with them.

. However, each of them can have additional parameters, which are called global parameters because they are specified globally for all requests. The SDK provides the ability to add global parameters once so that you don’t have to copy them when creating each request.
